Derek James wrote:

>What I'd like to know is, how do you tell if it is solving by
>oscillating?  Is this one doing that or no?  Would it be making very
>rapid movements in a small area?
>  
>
Derek, it's not terribly easy to tell from the movie. Both mine and 
Mattias' sims show the poles attached to differenet points on the cart. 
Mattias also chose to extend the short pole with a thin line ( I just 
drew the short pole longer than it is, which I should really change 
because it is misleading). Both of these things make observation easier.

 From what I can see though it seems your solution isn't suffering from 
the extreme wiggling that Gruau was trying to avoid. In his paper he 
states that the wiggling increases in amplitude very slowly and 
ultimately leads to the system becoming unstable, so one test is to see 
if your poles remain balanced in the simulator for a reasonable length 
of time.

On the other hand I've never properly implemented the anti-wiggle 
function since I've not seen the complete details. Are you using the 
function from the updated zip? If so this was just a 'home-brew' 
function /based/ on Gruau's, not his actual function. I've just scanned 
over his paper and it looks to me that he's evaluating over just 1000 
timesteps. So I've experimented with a fitness function that I think now 
matches his and I get solutions that can return the poles back to 
upright and generate hardly any movement at all, of either the poles or 
the cart. BUT! These solutions (and I've tried a handful) all become 
unstable sometime after 1000 timesteps have passed (e.g. the one I'm 
looking at failed at 2731, and a slight improvement on that one achieved 
7234). So I'd really need to read this paper properly to determine what 
he defines as a succesful solution, and whether I agree :) I'd certainly 
recommend you read it if you haven't yet, if for no other reason than to 
get the details of the fitness function correct. One thing I noticed is 
that I  /think/ he uses 4.5 degrees as the starting angle for the large 
pole, not one degree. Something that will make a solution harder to find 
I expect. I need to go and read the paper properly.

Colin.
